title: Health systems engineering
text:
Health Systems Engineering or Health Engineering (often known as "Health Care Systems Engineering (HCSE)") is an academic and a pragmatic discipline that approaches the <a href="health%20care">health care</a> industry, and other industries connected with health care delivery, as <a href="complex%20adaptive%20system">complex adaptive system</a>s, and identifies and applies engineering design and analysis principles in such areas. This can overlap with <a href="biomedical%20engineering">biomedical engineering</a> which focuses on design and development of various medical products; <a href="industrial%20engineering">industrial engineering</a> and <a href="operations%20management">operations management</a> which involve improving organizational operations; and various health care practice fields like <a href="medicine">medicine</a>, <a href="pharmacy">pharmacy</a>, <a href="dentistry">dentistry</a>, <a href="nursing">nursing</a>, etc. Other fields participating in this interdisciplinary area include <a href="public%20health">public health</a>, <a href="information%20technology">information technology</a>, <a href="management">management</a> studies, and regulatory <a href="law">law</a>.
People whose work implicates this field in some capacity can include members of all the above-noted fields, many of which have sub-fields targeted toward health care matters even if health or health care is not a principal focus of the overall field (e.g. management, law). Areas of <a href="biomedical%20engineering">biomedical engineering</a> (BME) in this area often include <a href="clinical%20engineering">clinical engineering</a> (sometimes also called "hospital engineering") as well as those BMEs developing <a href="medical%20devices">medical devices</a> and <a href="pharmaceutical%20drug">pharmaceutical drug</a>s. The <a href="industrial%20engineering">industrial engineering</a> (IE) principles employed tend to include optimization, decision analysis, <a href="human%20factors%20engineering">human factors engineering</a>, quality engineering, and value engineering.
